Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then when it solves we get a much more meaningful onchain diff than the current gradually increasing diff

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even if we 10x it, if there is 10000x the hash, it still finds a block in a second and we emitted coins we didnt have to

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so maybe calculate the max possible hashrate, based on recent blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: exponentially decay from that, to the current calc

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as long as the estimate is above the actual hashrate, then we can get a real valid diff sample

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which will then make the estimate for the max possible hashrate more accurate, though maybe we double it as we are dropping exponentially back to normally increasing diff

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and not much harm in overestimating the max possible hash

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess the question is, based on current solve times, how to calculate the max possible implied hashrate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well all denominated in bnTarget

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I am viewing the time less than expected for the recent blocks as a resource that we really want to spend. and the best usage of that is to get as close to the real hashrate as possible with the next sample. not sure on the math of how to calibrate the exponential decay to use up as close to all the time possible on the next block. but we now can temporarily have very large difficulty, but still decay it fast enough so it can be solved normally

Just thinking out loud......
if sum last 3 block < 0.2xT then bnTarget = (bnTarget \* min(1000, 1000*tipdiff/180)) / 1000;
